subtopics.name: Cell Structure
subtopics.theory:
Cells are the basic unit of life. All cells have a cell membrane, cytoplasm, and genetic material (DNA).

Prokaryotic cells (bacteria) lack a nucleus and membrane-bound organelles. Eukaryotic cells (animals, plants, fungi) have a nucleus and specialized organelles.

Key organelles: nucleus (DNA storage), mitochondria (energy production via cellular respiration), endoplasmic reticulum (protein and lipid synthesis), Golgi apparatus (packaging and transport), ribosomes (protein synthesis). Plant cells additionally have a cell wall, chloroplasts, and a large central vacuole.

examples.question: Compare and contrast plant and animal cells.

steps.title: Shared features
steps.explanation: Both have nucleus, mitochondria, ER, Golgi, ribosomes, cell membrane

steps.title: Plant cell only
steps.explanation: Cell wall (cellulose), chloroplasts, large central vacuole

steps.title: Animal cell only
steps.explanation: Centrioles, lysosomes (more prominent), no cell wall

examples.answer: Both are eukaryotic, but plant cells have cell walls, chloroplasts, and large vacuoles that animal cells lack.

subtopics.name: DNA & Heredity
subtopics.theory:
DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) carries genetic information as a double helix of nucleotides. Each nucleotide has a sugar, phosphate group, and one of four bases: Adenine (A), Thymine (T), Guanine (G), Cytosine (C). A pairs with T, G pairs with C.

Genes are segments of DNA that code for proteins. Alleles are different versions of a gene. Dominant alleles (capital letters) mask recessive alleles (lowercase).

Mendel's laws: Law of Segregation (alleles separate during gamete formation) and Law of Independent Assortment (genes on different chromosomes sort independently).

subtopics.name: Natural Selection
subtopics.theory:
Evolution is the change in allele frequencies in a population over time. Charles Darwin proposed natural selection as the primary mechanism.

Natural selection requires: (1) variation within a population, (2) heritable traits, (3) differential survival and reproduction based on traits, (4) traits that increase fitness become more common.

Evidence includes fossil records, homologous structures, DNA comparisons, and observed speciation. Speciation occurs when populations become reproductively isolated.

examples.question: Explain how antibiotic resistance develops in bacteria through natural selection.

steps.title: Variation exists
steps.explanation: Some bacteria have mutations giving antibiotic resistance

steps.title: Selection pressure
steps.explanation: Antibiotic kills susceptible bacteria, resistant ones survive

steps.title: Reproduction
steps.explanation: Resistant bacteria reproduce, passing on resistance genes

steps.title: Result
steps.explanation: Population shifts to mostly resistant bacteria

examples.answer: Natural selection favors bacteria with resistance mutations when antibiotics are present, leading to resistant populations.

subtopics.name: Circulatory System
subtopics.theory:
The circulatory system transports oxygen, nutrients, hormones, and waste products throughout the body. The heart is a four-chambered pump.

Blood flows: body â†’ right atrium â†’ right ventricle â†’ lungs (pulmonary circuit) â†’ left atrium â†’ left ventricle â†’ body (systemic circuit).

Arteries carry blood away from the heart (oxygenated in systemic). Veins carry blood toward the heart. Capillaries are tiny vessels where gas exchange occurs.

subtopics.name: Ecosystems
subtopics.theory:
An ecosystem includes all living organisms (biotic) and non-living components (abiotic) in an area interacting together.

Energy flows through trophic levels: producers â†’ primary consumers â†’ secondary consumers â†’ tertiary consumers. Only about 10% of energy transfers between levels.

Biogeochemical cycles (carbon, nitrogen, water) recycle matter. Biodiversity describes the variety of life and is essential for ecosystem stability. Human activities like deforestation and pollution threaten ecosystems.
